[[The New School]] | occupation = {{flatlist| * Actor * producer * screenwriter * director }} | years_active = 2004{{ndash}}present | net_worth = | spouse = | relatives = [[Beanie Feldstein]] (sister) }} '''Jonah Hill Feldstein''' (born December 20, 1983) is an American actor, director, producer, screenwriter, and comedian. Hill is known for his comedic roles in films such as ''[[Accepted (film)|Accepted]]'' (2006), ''[[Grandma's Boy (2006 film)|Grandma's Boy]]'' (2006), ''[[Superbad (film)|Superbad]]'' (2007), ''[[Knocked Up]]'' (2007), ''[[Forgetting Sarah Marshall]]'' (2008), ''[[Get Him to the Greek]]'' (2010), ''[[21 Jump Street (film)|21 Jump Street]]'' (2012), ''[[This Is the End]]'' (2013), ''[[22 Jump Street]]'' (2014), and ''[[War Dogs (2016 film)|War Dogs]]'' (2016), as well as his performances in ''[[Moneyball (film)|Moneyball]]'' (2011) and ''[[The Wolf of Wall Street (2013 film)|The Wolf of Wall Street]]'' (2013), for which he received [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nominations for [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]]. Hill ranked 28th on ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine's ranking of world's highest paid actors from June 2014 to June 2015, bringing in $16{{nbsp}}million.{{cite journal|last1=Robehmed|first1=Natalie|title=Seth Rogen, Jonah Hill Among Newcomers To Highest-Paid Actors List|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/natalierobehmed/2015/08/04/seth-rogen-jonah-hill-among-newcomers-on-highest-paid-actors-list/|work=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=August 4, 2015}} As a screenwriter, he contributed to the stories of ''21 Jump Street'', ''22 Jump Street'', ''[[Sausage Party]]'' and ''[[Why Him?]]'' (2016). Hill will make his directorial debut from a screenplay he wrote, titled ''[[Mid-90s (film)|Mid-90s]]. ==Early life== Jonah Hill Feldstein was born on December 20, 1983 in Los Angeles,{{cite journal|title=Jonah Hill|work=[[TV Guide]]|accessdate=April 11, 2015|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/jonah-hill/bio/281715/}} to Sharon Lyn ({{née|Chalkin}}), a [[costume designer]] and fashion stylist, and Richard Feldstein, a [[tour accountant]] for [[Guns N' Roses]].[http://levinsongenealogy.org/history/gp1500.htm#head0 Sharon CHALKIN, b: Private]. Levinsongenealogy.org. Retrieved on November 15, 2011.[https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30C17FA355D127A93C6AB178AD95F408785F9 Social Announcements – Weddings Engagements Births – Article – NYTimes.com]. Select.nytimes.com. Retrieved on November 15, 2011.Brevet, Brad. (June 2, 2010) [http://www.ropeofsilicon.com/article/interview-jonah-hill-talks-music-and-movies-promoting-get-him-to-the-greek Interview: Jonah Hill Talks Music and Movies Promoting 'Get Him to the Greek']. Rope of Silicon. Retrieved on November 15, 2011. He has a sister, [[Beanie Feldstein]], who is an actress, and an elder brother, Jordan Feldstein (1977-2017), who was a music manager of [[Robin Thicke]] and [[Maroon 5]].{{cite web|last1=Stein|first1=Danielle|title=Jonah Hill|url=http://www.wmagazine.com/people/celebrities/2008/02/jonah_hill|website=W Magazine|publisher=Condé Nast|accessdate=August 21, parents were originally from [[Long Island]], [[New York (state)|New York]], and the family vacationed in the [[Catskill Mountains|Catskills]].{{cite news |url=http://jewishjournal.com/mobile_20111212/100073/|title= Jonah Hill: ‘Moneyball’s’ super-talented, super-nice Jewish boy [VIDEO]|work=[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles|Jewish Journal]]|last=Pfefferman|first=Naomi|date=January 11, 2012|accessdate=June 5, 2018}} He grew up in the wealthy Los Angeles neighborhood of [[Cheviot Hills, Los Angeles|Cheviot Hills]], where he continues to live to this day,{{cite web|url=http://playboysfw.kinja.com/talking-with-jonah-hill-1264841217|title=Talking With Jonah Hill|author=James Franco|date=|work=Playboy|accessdate=January 8, 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/aug/20/jonah-hill-funny-people|title=Jonah Hill: Hollywood's hardest working slacker|author=Ryan Gilbey|date=|work=the Guardian|accessdate=January 8, 2016}} and attended the Center for Early Education, [[Brentwood School (Los Angeles)|Brentwood School]], and then [[Crossroads School (Santa Monica, California)|Crossroads School]], in [[Santa Monica, California|Santa Monica]]. After graduating from high school in 2002, Hill attended [[Bard College]],{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/jan/12/jonah-hill-actor-wolf-of-wall-street|title=Jonah Hill: 'Snorting fake cocaine in a Scorsese movie is pretty iconic'|author=Hermione Hoby|work=the Guardian|accessdate=March 20, 2015}} [[The New School]]{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/jonah-hill-20850227 |title=Jonah Hill biography: Writer and actor Jonah Hill starred in the teen hit Superbad. In 2011, he received an Oscar nomination for his performance in Moneyball.|archive-url=http://www.biography.com/people/jonah-hill-20850227| archive-date=January 8, 2016 | accessdate= January 8, 2016}} and the [[University of Colorado Boulder]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/news/ni56106838/|title=Jonah Hill: I Owe Oscar Nomination to Seth Rogen and Judd Apatow|work=IMDb|accessdate=March 20, 2015}}{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2pJ0ZsY5uLA#t=13m40s|title=The Howard Stern Interviews Jonah Hill 06/03/14|date=June 10, 2014|work=YouTube|accessdate=March 20, 2015}} Hill is Jewish,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/12/magazine/12wwln-Q4-t.html|title=Superdude|last=Solomon|first=Deborah|date=August 12, 2007|work=[[The New York Times]]|quote=Jonah Hill: "I’m a nice Jewish boy."|access-date=July 2, 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/jun/05/jonah-hill-who-i-am-22-jump-street|title= Jonah Hill: 'Having a bad day doesn't reflect who I am as a person'|work=[[The Guardian]]|first=Hadley|last=Freeman|date= June 5, 2014|accessdate= April 18, 2018}}{{Cite news|url=http://jewishjournal.com/blogs/125815/jonah-hills-not-so-nice-jewish-guy/|title=Jonah Hill’s not-so-nice Jewish guy|last=Pfefferman|first=Naomi|date=January 6, 2014|work=[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles|Jewish Journal]]|access-date=July 2, 2018|quote=Jonah Hill: "Being someone who’s Jewish"}} and had a [[Bar and Bat Mitzvah|Bar Mitzvah]] ceremony.{{cite news |url=http://jewishjournal.com/culture/arts/229277/hello-beanie-feldstein-moment-dolly-lady-bird/|title= Hello, Beanie: Feldstein Having a Moment With ‘Dolly’ and ‘Lady Bird’|work=[[The Jewish Journal web|url=https://www.jta.org/2017/07/26/arts-entertainment/the-summer-that-judd-apatow-seth-rogen-and-jonah-hill-took-over-mainstream-comedy|title=The summer that Judd Apatow, Seth Rogen and Jonah Hill took over mainstream comedy|last=Friedman|first=Gabe|date=July 26, 2017|website=[[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]]|language=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 5, 2018}}{{Cite 2012|work=[[J. The Jewish News of Northern California]]|access-date=July 2, 2018}} ==Career== [[File:Jonah Hill by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Hill at 2010 [[San Diego Comic Con International]]]] ===Early work=== In college, Hill began writing his own plays and performing them in the ''Black and White'' bar in the [[East Village, Manhattan|East Village]] neighborhood of New York City."[http://www.hobotrashcan.com/2006/08/03/one-on-one-with-jonah-hill/ One on One with... Jonah Hill]", ''Hobo Trashcan'', August 2006. Retrieved on June 29, 2007. His plays developed a small following and helped him realize that his true desire was to act in films. Hill was befriended by [[Dustin Hoffman|Dustin Hoffman's]] children, Rebecca and [[Jake Hoffman|Jake]], who introduced Hill to their father. The elder Hoffman asked him to audition for a role in ''[[I Heart Huckabees]]'', in which Hill made his film debut.{{cite web|last1=Young|first1=Molly|title=Jonah Hill Is No Joke|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/07/magazine/jonah-hill-is-no-joke.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=January 16, 2018|date=August 4, 2016}} Hill then made a brief appearance in [[Judd Apatow|Judd Apatow's]] directorial debut ''[[The 40-Year-Old Virgin]]'',{{cite web|last1=Guerrasio|first1=Jason|title=Jonah Hill's 9 Funniest Moments|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2808892/jonah-hill-funniest-scenes/|publisher=[[MTV]]|accessdate=January 16, 2018|date=December 6, 2011}} which eventually led to his appearing in the role of a virgin video game tester in the comedy ''[[Grandma's Boy (2006 film)|Grandma's Boy]]'' (2006) and featuring in the comedies ''[[Accepted]]'' and ''[[Click (2006 film)|Click]]'', playing [[Adam Sandler]]'s character's son in the latter film.{{cite web|last1=Caroll|first1=Larry|title=Justin Long, Jonah Hill Hope To Be 'Accepted' Into Adam Sandler Film|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1537540/justin-long-jonah-hill-hope-to-be-accepted-into-adam-sandler-film/|publisher=[[MTV]]|accessdate=January 16, 2018|date=July 31, 2006}} Hill was featured in a larger supporting role in the Apatow-directed ''[[Knocked Up]]'' (2007). On television, Hill played the "RA Guy" on the first season of the [[Oxygen Network]] sitcom ''[[Campus Ladies]]''. He guest-starred in an episode of ''[[Clark and Michael]]''.{{YouTube|jqz51mP9xX4|''Clark and Michael'' – Episode 8 – "Writing Partners"}}, August 2, 2007 ===2007–2012=== His first leading role was in the Apatow-produced comedy ''[[Superbad (film)|Superbad]]''. Hill starred in the film alongside [[Michael Cera]], in roles based on the film's writers, [[Seth Rogen]] and [[Evan Goldberg]].{{cite web|last1=Aquino|first1=Tara|title=11 Super Great Facts About ‘Superbad’|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/66546/11-super-great-facts-about-superbad|website=[[Mental Floss]]|accessdate=March 30, 2016|date=July 23, 2015}} The film is often cited as the film that launched the careers of the two actors.{{cite web|last1=Rabin|first1=Nathan|title=Christopher Mintz-Plasse of Superbad|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/jonah-hill-michael-cera-and-christopher-mintz-plas-14140|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=March 30, 2016|date=August 15, 2007}} He followed it with an uncredited role as Dewey Cox's grown-up brother, Nate Cox, in ''[[Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story]]'' in December 2007.{{cite web|last1=Chitwood|first1=Scott|title=Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/reviews/40330-walk-hard-the-dewey-cox-story-2|website=[[ComingSoon.net]]|accessdate=March 30, 2016|date=December 17, 2007}} He hosted ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' on March 15, 2008, which featured musical guest [[Mariah Carey]].{{cite web|last1=Coggan|first1=Devan|title=Jonah Hill hosts SNL: Talk about it here|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/03/05/saturday-night-live-jonah-hill-hosts-future|website=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=March 30, 2016|date=March 5, 2016}} He turned down a role as one of the three principal comedic actors in ''[[The Hangover]]'' so he could work with directors [[Jay Duplass]] and [[Mark Duplass]] in ''[[Cyrus (2010 comedy-drama film)|Cyrus]]'' (2010).{{cite web |url=https://www.howardstern.com/show/2014/1/21/jonah-hill-academy-award-nominated-superfan/ |title=Jonah Hill: Academy Award-nominated Superfan |date=January 21, 2014 |accessdate=July 24, 2016 |quote= |publisher=[[Howard Stern Show]] }}{{cite news |author=Angie Han |title=Jonah Hill Turned Down ‘The Hangover’ to Focus on Dramatic Acting |url=http://www.slashfilm.com/trivia-jonah-hill-turned-down-the-hangover-to-focus-on-dramatic-acting/ |quote= |newspaper=[[Slashfilm]] |date=June 27, 2013 }}{{cite news | author = Nicole Sperling | title = Jonah Hill no longer in talks for 'Transformers 2' | work = Entertainment Weekly | date = May 6, 2008 | url = http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2008/05/jonah-hill.html | accessdate = May 7, 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080509022701/http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2008/05/jonah-hill.html | archivedate = May 9, 2008 | df = mdy-all }} He guest-starred in an [[List of Reno 911! episodes#Season 6: 2009|episode]] of ''[[Reno 911!]]'', which aired on April 1, 2009.{{cite web|last1=Chavez|first1=Danette|title=Cary Fukunaga to direct Emma Stone and Jonah Hill in dark comedy series|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/cary-fukunaga-direct-emma-stone-and-jonah-hill-dar-233987|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=March 30, 2016|date=March 18, 2016}} He next starred in Judd Apatow's third directorial feature, ''[[Funny People]]'' (2009), which also starred [[Adam Sandler]], [[Eric Bana]] and Seth Rogen. He was an associate producer of the 2009 [[Sacha Baron Cohen]] [[mockumentary]] ''[[Brüno]]''.{{cite news | author=Michael Fleming | title = Trio joins Judd Apatow film |work=Variety | date = June 11, 2008 | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117987337.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 | accessdate=June 13, 2008}} He guest starred on an episode of ''[[The Simpsons]]'' called "[[Pranks and Greens]]", portraying an immature man named Andy Hamilton who was hailed the best prankster in Springfield Elementary School history.{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.ign.com/dor/objects/823209/thesimpsons/videos/simpsons_jean_012809.html|title=The Simpsons TV Interview – Al Jean |date=January 29, 2009|accessdate=January 30, 2009|publisher=IGN}} [[File:Jonah_Hill_TIFF_2011.jpg|thumb|upright|Hill at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] 2011 after a significant weight loss]] In July 2011, Hill appeared at ESPN's ESPY awards sporting a much slimmer physique. He stated he had lost 40 pounds. In November 2011, Hill, along with [[Sam Worthington]] and [[Dwight Howard]], starred in commercials for the video game ''[[Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3]]'', making his first appearance with his new look.{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5856653/jonah-hill-stars-in-this-live-action-call-of-duty-modern-warfare-3-ad|title=Jonah Hill, Sam Worthington Star in This Live Action Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 Ad|publisher=Kotaku|first=Brian|last=Crecente|date=November 4, 2011}} Also in 2011, Hill, alongside [[Andrew Mogel]] and [[Jarrad Paul]], created ''[[Allen Gregory]]'',{{cite web|title=FOX Announces 2011 Fall TV Premiere Dates|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/06/23/fox-announces-2011-fall-premiere-dates/96394/}} a cartoon series that received extremely negative reviews{{cite web|title=Allen Gregory : Season 1 |url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/allen-gregory/critic-reviews|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=August 6, 2016}} and was officially cancelled by Fox on January 8, 2012.{{cite web|author=Ausiello, Michael|title=Fox Boss Offers Renewal Updates on House, Fringe, Terra Nova and More!|url=http://tvline.com/2012/01/08/fox-house-fringe-terra-nova-renewals-cancellations/|publisher=TV Line|date=January 8, 2012}} Hill received a [[69th Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe]] nomination, his first nomination, for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor – Motion Picture|Best Performance by an Actor in a Supporting Role in a Motion Picture]] for his performance in the 2011 sports film ''[[Moneyball (film)|Moneyball]]'', in which he portrayed his first dramatic role as Peter Brand.{{cite web|title=Few surprises in Golden Globe nominations|url=http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/9464905-421/few-surprises-in-golden-globe-nominations.html|work=Suntimes.com}} In late January 2012, Hill received his first [[Academy Award|Oscar]] nomination for Best Actor in a Supporting Role for his role in ''Moneyball''.{{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/84/nominees.html |title=Nominees for the 84th Academy Awards | Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences |publisher=Oscars.org |date= |accessdate=February 21, 2012}} In 2012, Hill co-starred with [[Channing Tatum]] in the film ''[[21 Jump Street (film)|21 Jump Street]]'', and with [[Ben Stiller]] and [[Vince Vaughn]] in the film ''[[The Watch (2012 film)|The Watch]]''.{{cite news|last=Wloszczyna|first=Susan|title=Jonah Hill forms 'Neighborhood Watch' with Ben Stiller, Vince Vaughn|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2011/09/jonah-hill-forms-neighborhood-watch-with-ben-stiller-vince-vaughn/1|accessdate=December 25, 2011|newspaper=USA Today|date=September 23, 2011}} In 2011, it was announced that Hill was in talks to appear in [[Quentin Tarantino|Quentin Tarantino's]] film ''[[Django Unchained]]''.[http://reservoirwatchdogs.com/2011/11/09/jonah-hill-turned-down-django-unchained/ Jonah Hill turned down ‘Django Unchained’ |]. Reservoirwatchdogs.com (November 9, 2011). Retrieved on November 15, 2011. Hill almost had to decline a possible role due to his prior commitment to ''The Watch'', lamenting that to act in a Tarantino movie was "the perfect next step" in his career. Hill later rejoined ''Django Unchained'', which was released in 2012.{{cite news|last=White|first=James|title=Jonah Hill Joins Django Unchained|url=http://www.empireonline.com/news/story.asp?NID=34295|accessdate=June 17, 2012|date=June 17, 2012}} He was invited to join the [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] in June 2012 along with 175 other individuals.{{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/press/pressreleases/2012/20120629a.html|title=Academy Invites 176 to Membership|publisher=The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences|date=June 29, 2012|accessdate=July 19, 2013}} ===2013–present=== In 2013, Hill appeared in ''[[This Is the End]]'' as himself and the biographical film ''[[The Wolf of Wall Street (2013 film)|The Wolf of Wall Street]]''.{{cite web|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2013/06/05/jonah-hill-this-is-the-end-interview/|title=Jonah Hill, Serious Actor, didn't come here to talk about farting|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|date=June 5, 2013|accessdate=December 26, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/jonah-hill-the-wolf-of-wall-street/|title=Jonah Hill Joins Leonardo DiCaprio in Martin Scorsese’s THE WOLF OF WALL STREET|publisher=Collider.com|date=August 2, 2012|accessdate=December 26, 2013}} Hill was nominated for his second Academy Award for his work in the latter film. In an interview with [[Howard Stern]] on January 21, 2014, Hill said he earned {{USD}}60,000 for his role in ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' because Hill took SAG’s "minimum wage".[https://variety.com/2014/film/news/jonah-hill-was-paid-60000-for-wolf-of-wall-street-1201066745/ Jonah Hill Was Paid $60,000 for ‘Wolf of Wall Street’]. January 22, 2014. Hill told Stern he did not mind getting minimum pay because he "would have done anything in the world" for a role in a Scorsese film.{{cite web|last=Ward|first=Alexandra|title=Jonah Hill Made Paltry $60,000 for Doing 'The Wolf of Wall Street'|url=http://www.newsmax.com/thewire/jonah-hill-wolf-wall-street/2014/01/22/id/548350|publisher=Newsmax|accessdate=January 23, 2014}} He voiced the [[Green Lantern]] in the adventure comedy ''[[The Lego Movie]]'' in February 2014, which blends [[computer animation]] and [[live action]].{{cite web|last1=Staff|first1=THR|title=Channing Tatum, Jonah Hill, Cobie Smulders Added to 'Lego Movie' Voice Cast|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/channing-tatum-jonah-hill-cobie-589535|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=March 30, 2016|date=July 20, 2013}} Hill reprised his role as Morton Schmidt in ''[[22 Jump Street]]'' (2014), the sequel to ''21 Jump Street''.{{cite web|last1=Robey|first1=Tim|title=22 Jump Street, review: 'same plot, better jokes'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/filmreviews/10878257/22-Jump-Street-review-same-plot-better-jokes.html|website=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=March 30, 2016|date=June 5, 2014}} His next performance was as [[Michael Finkel]] in ''[[True Story (film)|True Story]]'' (2015), a mystery thriller, alongside James Franco.{{cite web|last1=Calhoun|first1=John|title=The True Story Behind 'True Story'|url=http://www.biography.com/news/true-story-movie-michael-finkel-christian-longo|website=Biography|accessdate=March 30, 2016|date=April 17, 2015}} In 2016, he played a [[surety]] agent for a production company in the [[Coen brothers]]' period comedy ''[[Hail, Caesar!]]'' and starred alongside [[Miles Teller]] in the biographical crime war comedy-drama ''[[War Dogs (2016 film)|War Dogs]]'', playing [[arms dealer]] [[Efraim Diveroli]], in August 2016.{{cite web|last1=Sims|first1=David|title=Have the Coen Brothers Made Peace With Hollywood?|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/02/hail-caesar-coen-brothers-barton-fink/461922/|website=[[The Atlantic]]|accessdate=March 30, 2016|date=February 10, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Eisenberg|first1=Eric|title=The Weird Character Trait That Got Jonah Hill In Character For War Dogs|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/news/1546560/the-weird-character-trait-that-got-jonah-hill-in-character-for-war-dogs|website=Cinema Blend|accessdate=August 28, 2016|date=August 2016}} In ''[[The Guardian]]'', Wendy Ide wrote of his performance, "Jonah Hill is so repellent – all swagger, sweat and unapologetic sexism – in ''War Dogs'', that for a while, you don’t immediately realise what a blitzkrieg of a performance he delivers."{{cite web|last1=Ide|first1=Wendy|title=War Dogs review – Jonah Hill is repellently brilliant|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/aug/28/war-dogs-review-jonah-hill-repellently-brilliant|website=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=August 28, 2016|date=August 28, 2016}} Hill also co-starred as a sausage named Carl in [[adult animation|adult]] [[computer animation|computer-animated]] [[comedy film|comedy]] film ''[[Sausage Party]]'', alongside [[Seth Rogen]], [[Kristen Wiig]], [[Bill Hader]], [[Michael Cera]], and [[James Franco]], in the same month.{{cite web|last1=Goldberg|first1=Matt|title=Writer Evan Goldberg and Executive Producer James Weaver Talk R-Rated Animated Film SAUSAGE PARTY; Pixar Movies Will Get "Ripped Apart"|url=http://collider.com/sausage-party-story-details-evan-goldberg/|website=[[Collider (website)|Collider]]|accessdate=August 28, 2016|date=May 5, 2014}} Hill will next star opposite [[Joaquin Phoenix]], [[Rooney Mara]] and [[Jack Black]] in ''[[Don't Worry, He Won't Get Far on Foot]]'' directed by [[Gus Van Sant]].{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/jonah-hill-rooney-mara-joaquin-phoenix-gus-van-sant-movie-1201942349/|title=Jonah Hill, Rooney Mara in Talks to Join Joaquin Phoenix in Gus Van Sant Film (EXCLUSIVE)|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|first=Justin|last=Kroll|date=December 16, 2016|accessdate=March 6, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/jack-black-joaquin-phoenix-gus-van-sant-movie-1201989664/|title=Jack Black in Talks to Join Joaquin Phoenix in Gus Van Sant’s John Callahan Biopic|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|first=Dave|last=McNary|date=February 15, 2017|accessdate=March 6, 2017}} He directed the music video for [[Danny Brown (rapper)|Danny Brown]]'s song "Ain't It Funny" in 2017, featuring Van Sant.{{cite web|url=http://www.vibe.com/2017/03/danny-brown-aint-it-funny-video-directed-by-jonah-hill/|title=Jonah Hill Directed Danny Brown's 'Ain't It Funny'
